title: Nazi concentration camp guard on trial at 93 over deaths of 5,230 people
text:

A Nazi concentration camp guard has gone on trial over the deaths of 5,230 people.

Bruno D, 93, arrived at court in a wheelchair wearing a broad-brim­­med hat and shielded his face with a folder as an official wheeled him in.

In what could be one of Germany’s last trials of Nazi war crimes, he was accused of sup­­­port­­­ing “insidious and cruel killing”. The former SS man, 17 or 18 at the time, manned watchtowers at Stutthof Camp near what is now Gdansk, Poland.

More than 60,000 prisoners, nearly half of them Jews, died there between 1939 and 1945. Many were killed in its gas chamber while others succumbed to hunger, sickness and exhaustion.

Prosecutors argue that Bruno D was an accessory to murder as he stopped inmates escaping. Because he was a teenager at the time, the case is being tried in a youth court. Descendents

of sur­­­- vivors filled the public gal­­lery at the start of the hearing in Hamburg.

It was reported yesterday that there are 29 open cases in Germany against individuals accused of being involved in the Holocaust in which Adolph Hitler’s Nazis murdered more than 17 million people across Europe.
description: Bruno D was a guard at the Stutthof Camp near what is now Gdansk in Poland
